definitions: make a loud unpleasant noise that disturbs or annoys people
operate a dishonest or illegal business scheme to make money
examples: The kids were racketing around upstairs all night long
The construction workers racket outside my window every morning
He racketed for years before the police caught him
They racket by selling fake tickets to tourists downtown

definitions: engage in dishonest or illegal business activities to make money through threats
examples: The mob boss racketeered throughout the city for decades
They racketeer by forcing shop owners to pay protection money

definitions: send out light heat or energy in rays or waves from a central point
spread outward from a central point in all directions like rays
show an emotion or quality very clearly and strongly to others
examples: The sun radiates heat and light to warm the earth
The heater radiates warmth throughout the entire room comfortably
Pain radiated from her injured shoulder down her arm
The cracks radiated outward from where the rock hit
She radiates confidence whenever she enters a room
His face radiated joy when he saw his grandchildren

definitions: organize or participate in a lottery where people buy tickets to win prizes
examples: The school will raffle a new car to raise funds
They raffle gift baskets at the charity event annually

definitions: travel on water using a flat floating structure made of logs or materials
examples: We rafted down the river during our summer vacation
They plan to raft through the rapids next weekend

definitions: construct or support a roof structure using sloping wooden beams called rafters
examples: The carpenter will rafter the new house roof tomorrow
They raftered the barn using traditional building methods carefully

definitions: tease mock or criticize someone repeatedly in an annoying or harsh way
examples: His friends always rag him about his old car
Stop ragging on me for making one small mistake

definitions: make a sudden attack on a place or group to steal damage or capture
examples: The pirates raided coastal villages for treasure and supplies
Police raided the warehouse and found stolen goods inside

definitions: collect leaves grass or other materials using a tool with teeth or prongs
search through something very carefully and thoroughly to find items or information
earn or accumulate large amounts of money especially from business or gambling
examples: I need to rake the fallen leaves in my yard
She rakes the garden beds to remove dead plants
Detectives raked through evidence to find clues about suspects
He raked through old files looking for the contract
The casino rakes millions from tourists every single year
She rakes in huge profits from her online business

definitions: hit or push something very hard with great force to break or move it
force something through or into position using strength pressure or determination
examples: The truck rammed into the barrier at high speed
The goat rammed its head against the fence repeatedly
They rammed the new policy through despite strong opposition
He rammed the cork back into the wine bottle

definitions: walk for pleasure in the countryside without a planned route or destination
talk or write at length in a confused way without clear organization
examples: We rambled through the hills enjoying the autumn scenery
They love to ramble along country paths on weekends
He rambled on about his childhood for several hours
The speaker rambled and never got to the point

definitions: increase something gradually or progressively over a period of time
build or provide a sloping surface to connect different levels
examples: The company will ramp up production for the holidays
We need to ramp our efforts to meet deadlines
They ramped the entrance to make it wheelchair accessible
The contractor will ramp the driveway for easier access

definitions: move through a place in a violent and uncontrolled way causing damage
examples: The angry crowd rampaged through the streets breaking windows
Wild elephants rampaged through the village destroying crops yesterday

definitions: pay money to free someone who has been captured or kidnapped by criminals
examples: The family ransomed their kidnapped son for two million
Pirates ransomed the captured sailors back to their countries

definitions: speak or shout at length in an angry passionate and uncontrolled way
examples: He ranted about politics for an hour at dinner
She ranted at the customer service representative on phone

definitions: hit something quickly and sharply making a knocking sound
perform a type of music with rhythmic speech over backing beats
criticize or punish someone sharply for their actions or behavior
examples: She rapped on the door three times before entering
The teacher rapped the desk to get students' attention
He raps at local clubs every Friday night downtown
They rap about social issues in their latest album
The judge rapped the company for safety violations harshly
Critics rapped the movie for its poor acting quality

definitions: make a harsh grating sound especially when speaking or breathing
scrape or file something with a rough tool to shape or smooth
examples: His voice rasped from shouting at the football game
The old door rasped whenever someone opened it slowly
The carpenter rasped the wood to smooth its rough edges
She rasped the metal surface before painting it carefully

definitions: increase or decrease something gradually in a series of small steps
move or adjust using a mechanical device with teeth that allows one-way movement
examples: They ratchet up prices every year without improving quality
Tensions ratchet higher as the deadline approaches each day
He ratcheted the jack to lift the car for repairs
The mechanic ratcheted the bolt until it was tight

definitions: formally approve or confirm an agreement treaty or contract to make it official
examples: Congress must ratify the trade agreement before it's valid
All members ratified the new constitution by unanimous vote

definitions: control the amount of something that people are allowed to have when scarce
examples: The government rationed food during the war years carefully
We need to ration our water during the drought

definitions: attempt to explain or justify behavior or attitude with logical reasons even if inappropriate
organize a business or system in a more logical and effective way
examples: He tried to rationalize his poor decision to investors
She rationalized eating the cake by calling it breakfast
The company will rationalize its operations to cut costs
They rationalized the production process to improve efficiency significantly

definitions: make a series of short sharp sounds when shaken or moving
make someone nervous worried or unable to think clearly
examples: The windows rattle whenever a truck drives past outside
Keys rattled in his pocket as he walked quickly
The accident really rattled her for several days afterward
Don't let his harsh comments rattle you before performing

definitions: cause severe and extensive damage or destruction to a place or thing
examples: The hurricane ravaged the coastal towns leaving widespread destruction
War ravaged the country for more than ten years

definitions: speak or write about something with great enthusiasm or admiration
attend or organize a large party with dancing and electronic music
examples: Critics raved about her performance in the new movie
He raved about the restaurant's food to his friends
They raved all night at the warehouse party downtown
Thousands of people rave at the music festival annually

definitions: tangle or untangle threads fibers or other materials into knots or confusion
examples: The yarn raveled into a mess in her knitting basket
She carefully raveled out the tangled fishing line slowly

definitions: seek or seize food or prey hungrily like a wild bird or animal
examples: The wolves raven for food during the harsh winter
Vultures raven on the carcass in the desert heat

definitions: completely destroy a building or structure by knocking it down to ground level
examples: They will raze the old factory to build apartments
The city razed several abandoned buildings for safety reasons

definitions: cut or shave hair from skin using a sharp-edged cutting instrument
examples: He razors his beard every morning before work carefully
The barber razored the customer's neck for a clean finish

definitions: restore something to an active working state after a period of inactivity
examples: Please reactivate my gym membership starting next month immediately
The company will reactivate the old production line soon

definitions: state something again strongly to confirm its continuing truth importance or validity
examples: The president reaffirmed his commitment to education reform publicly
She reaffirmed her love for him on their anniversary

definitions: change or restore something to a different or correct position or state
examples: The mechanic will realign your car's wheels for better handling
The company needs to realign its goals with market demands

definitions: become fully aware of something as a fact or truth suddenly
achieve or make something that was planned or hoped for actually happen
examples: I suddenly realised I had forgotten my wallet at home
She realised her mistake only after submitting the report
He finally realised his dream of opening a restaurant
They realised huge profits from their investment last year

definitions: enlarge or shape a hole using a rotating cutting tool
criticize or reprimand someone very severely and at length
examples: The plumber will ream the pipe to fix the blockage
He reamed the metal tube to the correct size
The boss reamed him out for missing the important deadline
She got reamed by her parents for staying out late

definitions: cut and gather crops or harvest when they are ready
receive something as a result of your own or others' actions
examples: Farmers reap wheat in late summer when it's golden
They reap the corn by hand in small villages
You will reap the benefits of your hard work eventually
Companies that invest wisely reap huge profits over time

definitions: come into sight or existence again after being gone hidden or absent
examples: The sun reappeared after the storm clouds passed overhead
The missing cat reappeared at the door three days later

definitions: care for and bring up children or animals until they are fully grown
rise up on the hind legs or raise something up high
examples: They reared five children in that small house successfully
Farmers rear cattle for meat and dairy products locally
The horse reared when it saw the snake nearby
The mountain rears high above the surrounding valley magnificently

definitions: change the position order or time of things to organize them differently
examples: Let's rearrange the furniture to create more space here
She rearranged her schedule to attend the important meeting

definitions: put the parts of something together again after taking it apart
examples: The mechanic will reassemble the engine after cleaning it
Students reassembled the skeleton model for biology class carefully

definitions: state something again firmly and forcefully to make your position clear
examples: He reasserted his innocence despite the accusations against him
The company reasserted its commitment to environmental protection publicly

definitions: think about something again carefully to form a new opinion or judgment
examples: We need to reassess our strategy after these poor results
The doctor will reassess your condition in two weeks

definitions: give someone a different job task or position than they had before
examples: The manager will reassign duties among the team members
They reassigned him to the London office last month

definitions: say or do something to remove someone's doubts fears or worries
examples: The doctor reassured us that the surgery went well
She reassured her crying child with a warm hug

definitions: pay back part of the money that someone has paid for something
examples: The store will rebate fifty dollars on all appliances
They rebated the overcharged amount to customers immediately yesterday

definitions: shut down and restart a computer or electronic device to refresh its operation
examples: Please reboot your computer to install the new updates
I had to reboot my phone when it froze completely

definitions: bounce back after hitting a surface or spring back into position
recover quickly from a setback disappointment or difficult situation
examples: The basketball rebounded off the rim into his hands
The ball rebounded high after hitting the concrete floor
Stock prices rebounded after yesterday's sharp decline in trading
She rebounded quickly from her divorce and found happiness

definitions: transmit a television or radio program again at a different time
examples: They will rebroadcast the game tomorrow at noon exactly
The station rebroadcasts old shows during late night hours

definitions: express sharp disapproval or criticism of someone because of their behavior
examples: The teacher rebuked the student for cheating on the test
She rebuked him publicly for his rude comments yesterday

definitions: claim or prove that evidence or an accusation is false with opposing arguments
examples: The lawyer will rebut the prosecution's claims in court
Scientists rebutted the study with their own research findings

definitions: say formally that you no longer believe something you previously said publicly
examples: The witness recanted his testimony under pressure from lawyers
She refused to recant her controversial statements about politics

definitions: give a brief summary of the main points of something that happened
examples: Let me recap what we discussed in today's meeting
The coach will recap the game plan before kickoff
